SPECIAL ORDERS. }
No. 18. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPT. OF WESTERN CUBA,
Quemados, August 14, 1900.

1. Captain Curtis B. Hoppin, Quartermaster, 2d Cavalry,
having relieved Major W. H. Miller, Disbursing Quarter-
master of the former Department of Matanzas and Santa
Clara, per General Orders No. 15, series 1900, those head-
quarters, will comply with the provisions of paragraph 2,
Special Orders No. 134, series 1900, Headquarters Depart-
ment of Matanzas and Santa Clara, in so far as directs the
transfer of all funds, property, papers, etc., relating to
public work ordered at Corral Falso, Cuba, to Captain H.
B. Chamberlin, Assistant Quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers,
Colón, Cuba.
2. A board of survey, to consist of:
Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. V., Chief Surgeon;
2d Lieutenant C. F. Armistead, 2d Artillery;

will assemble at Pinar del Rio Barracks, as soon as practi-
cable, for the purpose of investigating and deciding on the
disposition that should be made of medical property (and
stores) left at that post.

The property at this post having been more or less ex-
posed to infection of yellow fever, every precaution will be
taken before any of it is shipped to other points, and this
will be carefully considered by the board. Instructions
from Division Headquarters direct that no property be
shipped to the Havana depots which has in any way been
exposed to infection. The board will furnish the quarter-
master and the accountable officer with a list of property
which is not considered in any way infected. This prop-
erty will then be shipped as promptly as possible by the
quartermaster to the supply depot at Havana.

All unserviceable property that requires the action of a
board of survey before being submitted to an inspector;
and all serviceable property requiring it, but which can be
safely disinfected, will be reported upon by the board.
With the exception of property which should be retained in
the service, this property will be put upon inventory and
inspection reports and held in readiness to be submitted to
an inspector for action. Any disinfected property that
should be retained in the service will be reported to these
headquarters for further orders regarding its disposition.
Infected property to be destroyed will be disposed of as re-
quired by A. R. 1441.
3. A board of survey, to consist of:
Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. V., Chief Surgeon;
2d Lieutenant L. W. Oliver, 7th Cavalry;

will assemble at Guanajay Barracks, as soon as practicable,
for the purpose of investigating and deciding on the dispo-
sition that should be made of medical property (and stores)
left at that post.

The property at this post having been more or less ex-
posed to inspection of yellow fever, every precaution will be
taken before any of it is shipped to other points, and this
will be carefully considered by the board. Instructions
from Division Headquarters direct that no property be
shipped to the Havana depots which has in any way been
exposed to infection. The board will furnish the quarter-
master and the accountable officer with a list of property
which is not considered in any way infected. This prop-
erty will then be shipped as promptly as possible by the
quartermaster to the supply depot at Havana.

All unserviceable property that requires the action of a
board of survey before being submitted to an inspector:
and all serviceable property requiring it, but which can be
safely disinfected, will be reported upon by the board.
With the exception of property which should be retained in
the service, this property will be put upon inventory and
inspection reports and held in readiness to be submitted to
an inspector for action. Any disinfected property that
should be retained in the service will be reported to these
headquarters for further orders regarding its disposition.
Infected property to be destroyed will be disposed of as re-
quired by A. R. 1441.
4. A board of survey, to consist of:
Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. V., Chief Surgeon;
Acting Assistant Surgeon Raoul A. Amador, U. S. Army;

will assemble at Pinar del Rio Barracks, as soon as practi-
cable, for the purpose of investigating and deciding on the
disposition that should be made of quartermaster, engineer,
signal, ordnance and subsistence property (including stores)
left at that post.

The property at this post having been more or less ex-
posed to infection of yellow fever, every precaution will be
taken before any of it is shipped to other points, and this
will be carefully considered by the board. Instructions
from Division Headquarters direct that no property be
shipped to the Havana depots which has in any way been
exposed to infection. The board will furnish the quarter-
master and the accountable officer with a list of property
which is not considered in any way infected. This prop-
erty will then be shipped as promptly as possible by the
quartermaster to the supply depots at Havana.

All unserviceable property that requires the action of a
board of survey before being submitted to an inspector;
and all serviceable property requiring it, but which can be
safely disinfected, will be reported upon by the board, each
class separately. With the exception of property which
should be retained in the service, this property will be put
upon proper inventory and inspection reports, and held in
readiness to be submitted to an inspector for action. Any
disinfected property that should be retained in the service
will be reported to these headquarters for further orders re-
garding its disposition. Infected property to be destroyed
will be disposed of as required by A. R. 1441.
5. A board of survey, to consist of:
Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. V., Chief Surgeon;
Acting Assistant Surgeon Robert P. Cooke, U. S. Army;

will assemble at Guanajay Barracks, as soon as practicable,
for the purpose of investigating and deciding on the dispo-
sition that should be made of quartermaster, engineer, sig-
nal, ordnance and subsistence property (including stores)
left at that post.

The property at this post having been more or less ex-
posed to infection of yellow fever, every precaution will be
taken before any of it is shipped to other points, and this
will be carefully considered by the board. Instructions
from Division Headquarters direct that no property be
shipped to the Havana depots which has in any way been
exposed to infection. The board will furnish the quarter-
master and the accountable officer with a list of property
which is not considered in any way infected. This prop-
erty will then be shipped as promptly as possible by the
quartermaster to the supply depots at Havana.

All unserviceable property that requires the action of a
board of survey before being submitted to an inspector;
and all serviceable property requiring it, but which can be
safely disinfected, will be reported upon by the board, each
class separately. With the exception of property which
should be retained in the service, this property will be put
upon proper inventory and inspection reports, and held in
readiness to be submitted to an inspector for action. Any
disinfected property that should be retained in the service
will be reported to these headquarters for further orders re-
garding its disposition. Infected property to be destroyed
will be disposed of as required by A. R. 1441.

6. Major J. R. Kean, Chief Surgeon, will proceed to
Guanajay Barracks and Pinar del Rio Barracks for duty as
member of boards of survey convened to investigate and
report on disposition that should be made of Government
property left at those posts. On completion of this duty
he will rejoin his proper station.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

7. Captain T. B. Dugan, 7th Cavalry, Corporal William
Reese, Troop G, and Private Theodore O' Brien, Troop E,
7th Cavalry, will proceed to Pinar del Rio to-morrow morn-
ing, the 15th instant, reporting upon arrival to Major
George M. Dunn, Judge Advocate of the Department, for
duty in connection with the investigation of the murder of
the late Private Harry G. Crouch, Troop G, 7th Cavalry.

When no longer required at Pinar del Rio Captain Dugan
and the above named enlisted men will rejoin their proper
station.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:

R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General.
